thread.title: Anna Williamson 'wanted to die' during anxiety struggle despite 'amazing job' as children's TV star
thread.title_full: Anna Williamson 'wanted to die' during anxiety struggle despite 'amazing job' as children's TV star

author: Alistair McGeorge
title: Anna Williamson 'wanted to die' during anxiety struggle despite 'amazing job' as children's TV star
text:
Anna Williamson 'wanted to die' during anxiety struggle despite 'amazing job' as children's TV star The former CITV and Daybreak presenter has opened up about panic attacks and mental health Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Anna Williamson on her anxiety disorder and hitting rock bottom Share this video Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Former children's TV presenter Anna Williamson has admitted she "wanted to die" during her struggle with anxiety and panic attacks. 
The telly star had an "amazing job" but battled with her mental health before eventually admitting she needed to ask for help - and encouraged others to do the same after shifting careers to help people with similar problems. 
Promoting her self help book Breaking Mad: The Insider's Guide to Conquering Anxiety, the trained counsellor is also a ambassador for mental health charity Mind. Anna Williamson has opened up about her struggle with anxiety and panic attacks (Photo: Copyright unknown) 
"10 years ago I was at rock bottom. I felt like I genuinely wanted to die because I didn't know why I was feeling so bad," she said on ITV's Lorraine , while admitting she did have a happy life at the time. She has turned her attention to helping others (Photo: Copyright unknown) Anna urged people to ask for help (Photo: Copyright unknown) 
"[But] everything was clouded, everything was foggy." 
Anna admitted during the candid chat with stand-in host Helen Skelton that she felt like she was "going mad", but urged people to seek help and look out for themselves. She hit rock bottom 10 years ago (Photo: Copyright unknown) 
"First of all, you just need to set aside a time just for you," she added. 
"You have to find that 10 minutes, that hour... You are entitled to be on your own... Don't be a yes person, put yourself first." Like us on Facebook
